Hey it's me again, felt like asking another very specific and long winded question about your mental state as it reflects the themes and ideas of you music.

The new song "long long long journey" seems to me that it is split almost in half, or maybe thirds if you squint the right way, in regards to theme. The first part is incredibly somber and quite frankly depressing, exuding the feeling of exhaustion and trying to trick yourself into going forward (maybe this is just my personal experiences with depression and feeling desperate to keep moving, but the three lines about how far you've gone and then with the " and it's a long long long long long way back" to me feels more like a reminder that you can't change your mind now. Instead of being encouraging and motivating, to me it feels daunting and frightening that now you kind of have to keep going forward since you cant go back.)

Regardless of the first bits, the second part se ems to t ake a more positive outlook, especially with the last line with the "road" being to success. My best guess is that this song is about struggling to stay either motivated with a project or with life in general, that or it could be about depression and a kind of subliminal encouragement to those suffering that it DOES get better if you keep fighting. Those are my two best guesses. What do you think I'm mighty wurtz?

q.a: first you check for 3s, then check for 5s, (those are easy checks) then you gotta start checking for all the other primes one by one, from 7 and working your way up. if you rule them all out in order then you only have to go as high as the square root of the number and then you can stop. you can check the primes (like 7 for example) by maniuplating the target number by multiples of 7 until it gets to something recognizably a multiple of 7. there are endless amounts of useful/easy ways to do these manipulations, and you learn more tricks the more you do it

q.a: with the bass, just chroma key the red, and check the 'invert' box, so it will get rid of everything except that color. then you'll have to put that layer on top of another layer which still has everything in. then change the color of the one with just the bass. for the hair one, actually what's happening there is i've keyed IN the skin, so everything changes color. that was one of the first times i did this but now i do it all the time, it's the same trick i described with the bass except instead of taking the bass color i take my skin color, isolate it, then put it on top and then change the color of everything else. this essentially allows me to do the wild colors and i still look human

q.a: it was exciting and refreshing, and fun. the song i was gonna pick instead was of a similar level of complexity as the previous song. it would have been ok but i just felt more comfortable doing something much different. so i did moon cheese instead, and it was a wild ride and i had a wild fun time. but there seemed to be a universal response that the chords were just too strange. i know just as well as the next person to never use chords because they seem clever, ONLY if it actually works in the song and sounds good. i am very serious about this and i would not have done it unless i was sure that it sounded healthy strong and good, and i was convinced that it was healthy strong and good .... threw out many other versions which were not ... i was convinced that what i settled on was good and strong, and i was very excited about it. but, there was a universal response that this was not the case. and they must be right

q.a: the way that type of song uses the notation system is a bit oblique .... very normal but not a good starting point for learning chord symbols. i can tell you what chord goes there in that song, it's C# in the bass, and you're gonna want B, F, and E in the mid range. but it may not be clear how we get that from the C#7#9 chord symbol. to get the chord symbol thing a bit better, i think you should start in the key of C, and for your first example just play C major chord (the chord symbol for that is just C), and then add a Bb note to it. that is C7. that's just what that is. good starting place ...... when i was young, someone confided in me that C7 is the perfect way to signal you're about to go to the F chord. try it ... try a song in C, and play some things in the key of C and then drop that C7 and bam, the whole world knows it's time to go to F now. i think that's a good starting point ... that's where i started ... i'll never forget when i learned that. changed my life. i still use that principle in almost every song

My car broke down a couple days ago and a friend I haven't seen in 15 years heard about it and sent me enough money to pay not only the car, but next month's rent. Essentially, if my car hadn't broken down, I wouldn't have experienced this insane reconnection and blessing.

This planet seems to place a high premium on balance, so I try to remember when shit is hitting the proverbial fan that in order for the universe to balance things out, something equally wonderful is heading my way. In the flip, when something wonderful happens, I tend to brace myself for inevitable challenge.

Have you experienced anything like this in your own research?

q.a: that would be Dbmaj7, Caug7, Fmin9(11). honestly in that situation, over the Dbmaj7, Fmin pentatonic will be all you need. during the Caug7, honestly Bb will be your strongest note. still firmly think of F min but i guess don't really hang on the F note, technically you'd want the E note instead but don't hang on that either. and during the Fmin9(11) you'll probably have strong emphasis on those G and Bb notes and also Fmin. basically the whole time just consider Fmin pent stuff to be your home and the Bb note is gonna be really strong everywhere except the Dbmaj7 in which Ab and C (and F) will be stronger. this is all stuff you can find by just playing in F min and listening to which notes sound stronger when

q.a: i know world history overall quite well (i learned it in 2016 mostly) but that's not quite the situation you are talking about. to give you an example, when i was researching the history of the world for the history of the world video, almost every single name and event that i came across was something that i remembered being mentioned in highschool history class (byzantium, ivan the terrible, mohammad, confuscius, roman empire, etc etc etc every single thing) but i had not 1 single idea of when where who why whenst and what Any of those things were, in school. every single thing was mentioned, but like in the wrong order i think, and none of it felt real, probably because i was a teenager and i was still busy learning the present. If you wanna learn that stuff, task yourself with making an entire presentation of your own, in your wildest specifications, not under anyone's direction, where you are supposed to explain all that stuff. then you'll have to just go out and learn what you need somehow. you'll learn it very very well that way. but if you wanna pass someone else's test then i wouldn't know what to tell you ...maybe find their answer key?

q.a: pitch bend, and the other one. most keyboards have those 2 wheels. the pitch bend wheel is spring loaded and usually gives you a whole step either way (or you can set it different if u want) and the other wheel is not spring loaded, and does different things depending on the instrument but on many instruments it's vibrato. i mostly use it for vibrato, on that particular sound i have it for vibrato. but on many sounds i use it for filter cutoff ("wawa"). very useful, especially in getting your digital instrument to sound a bit more like something 'real'
